Problem:
Consider the linear operator \\(L[\\cdot]\\) defined as \\(L[x] = \\int_{0}^{\\infty} e^{-st} x(t) dt\\), often known as the Laplace Transform. We investigate different manipulations involving a second operator \\(M[\\cdot]\\) defined by \\(M[x] = x(t-a)\\) for some constant \\(a > 0\\), which is a time-delay transformation.

Applying the operator \\(M[\\cdot]\\) to a function \\(x(t)\\) and subsequently applying the Laplace Transform \\(L[\\cdot]\\), does this sequence yield the same result as directly applying \\(L[\\cdot]\\) to \\(x(t)\\) without the intervention of \\(M[\\cdot]\\)?
Explanation: The delay introduced by \\(M[x]\\) translates the function by \\(a\\), so the Laplace Transform will include a factor of \\(e^{-sa}\\), which alters the original Laplace Transform of the undelayed function. This results in \\(L[M[x]] = e^{-sa}L[x]\\), not merely \\(L[x]\\).

causal_map_integration: Applying the time-delay transformation M[•] to x(t) followed by the Laplace Transform L[•] yields the same result as directly applying L[•] to x(t), with the only difference being a multiplication by e^(-sa).
